choices.text: Height age equal to skeletal age

questions.text: Short stature, secondary to growth hormone deficiency is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Human growth hormone deficiency
A. Appear normal in height and weight at birth.
B. Delay on growth is usually after the age of 1 year. There is slow and regular growth. They gain less than 4 cm height a year.
C. Upper segment: Lower segment is normal
D. Bone age <chronological> 10 ng/ml excludes deficiency

questions.text: All of the following are the complications in the new born of a diabetic mother except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Infant of diabetic mother 
Clinical features
1. Macrosomia / large for gestational age 
2. Polycythemia which increases risk of 
A. Neonatal jaundice 
B. Renal vein thrombosis 
3. Neonatal hypoglycaemia 
4. Neonatal hypocalcemia
5. Surfactant deficiency (as insulin is antagonist to cortisol). There is higher incidence of respiratory distress syndrome

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate who was born at 32 weeks’ gestation has recovered from respiratory distress syndrome. He has been tolerating increasing volumes of enteral feedings via gavage. Over the past several feedings, abdominal distension, gastric residuals, and stools that are positive for blood have been noted. Of the following, the radiographic finding MOST supportive of the diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A 14 month old baby has diarrhoea with vomiting for 3 weeks. She also had measles a month back. On examination she is wasted, irritable, skin can be pinched up and tongue is moist, systemic examination revealed a slightly enlarged liver. Her weight is 6 Kg. She also has pedal oedema. Her grandmother who lives in same house have history of chronic cough. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: All are the major criteria suggested by Nadas except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A cyanotic new born is suspected of having CHD. He has a pan systolic murmur audible at left sternal border. Chest X-ray shows decreased pulmonary blood flow, oligemic lung fields. ECG shows left axis deviation. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tricuspid atresia
• Only cyanotic CHD associated with left ventricular hypertrophy 
• Hypoxic spell can be seen.

choices.text: IgG CMV antibodies in blood at birth
Saliva PCR within 3 weeks of birth
CMV viral DNA in blood by polymerase chain reaction

questions.text: Which of the following does not establish a diagnosis of congenital CMV infection in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Cytomegalovirus
1. Most common intrauterine infection 
2. Transmission:
• Vertical transmission can occur at any time in gestation or in the perinatal period.
• CMV is the leading infectious cause of sensonineural hearing loss (SNHL) and developmental delay.
• Microcephaly with periventricular calcification.
• Sensori neural hearing loss 
• CMV pneumonitis:
• IgG antibodies are not helpful in diagnosis as there is also intra-partum and post-partum transmission.

questions.text: Consider the following factors: 1. Head control, 2. Social Smile, 3. Crawls, 4. Sit up. The correct sequence in developmental milestones during the 1st year of life:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prone Position
a) Newborn: Pelvis high knees under abdomen, turns head from side to side
b) 1 month: Holds chin up
c) 4 months: Lifts head & chest with head in approximately vertical axis 
Complete Neck Control
d) 5 months: Rolls over
e) 8 months: Crawls 
f) 10 months: Creeps
g) 1 year: Walks on hands and feet like bear, (walking on extended arms & legs)
h) 15 Months: Crawls up the stairs

questions.text: A term new born presents with bilious vomiting shortly after birth. Her abdomen is distended slightly, and facial features are characteristic of Down syndrome. She has passed a normal meconium stool. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Of the following, the MOST likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Clinical features in the neonatal period
I. Poor moro’s reflex
II. Upward slanted palpebral fissures
III. Speckled irises (brush field spots)
IV. Three fontanels
V. Frontal sinus& mid facial hypoplasia
VI. Cardiovascular
• Endocardial cushion defect/av septal defect/ av canal defect – most common
• Ventricular septal defect
• ASD
• PDA
• Aberrant subclavian artery
These are in decreasing order of frequency 
VII. Single transverse palmar creases – simian crease
VIII. Wide gap between 1st and 2nd toes (sandle gap)
IX. Duodenal atresia (most common)

questions.text: Males who sexually underdeveloped with rudimentary testes and prostate glands, sparse pubic and facial hair, long arms and legs and large hand and feet are likely to have the chromosome complement of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Klinefelter syndrome:
A. Phenotypically male.
B. Most common cause ofhypogonadism& infertility in males
C. Most common sex chromosome aneuploidy in humans.
Clinical feature 
A. Puberty at normal age
B. Small testes 
C. Late secondary sex characters, 50

questions.text: A 7 ½ year old girl is brought with history that she has started having episodes of inattentiveness since 2 weeks. The episodes last 10 to 15 seconds and occur several times a day. There is no history of fall, convulsive movements, tongue bite or bladder/bowel incontinence during these periods:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Absence seizures:-
Typical – usually start at 5-8 years of age. (Sudden brief lapse of consciousness without loss of posture control)
• Do not have an aura
• Usually last for only a few seconds.
• Do not have a postictal period
• Hyper ventilation for 3-5 min can precipitate the seizures.
• Associated with 3 Hz spike and wave discharges that begins & ends suddenly super imposed on a normal EEG background.

questions.text: Most common sequelae due to periventricular leukomalacia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diplegic type
A. Commonly seen in babies born preterm with associated problems of intraventricular haemorrhage & periventricular leucomalacia.
B. Increased adductor tone & scissoring is seen in infancy.
C. Commando crawl is seen
D. No mental retardation

questions.text: Blood specimen for neonatal thyroid screening is obtained on:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Newborn screening – when to screen 
A. Normal hospital delivery at term – ideally at 2 – 4 days of age 
B. NICU / preterm home birth – within 7 days of birth 
C. Maternal history of thyroid medication / family history of congenital hypothyroidism – cord blood for screening

choices.text: Treatment of choice to prevent virilisation in the prenatal period is hydrocortisone
Female child has enlarge clitoris & fusion of labia
Boys with CAH have normal external genitalia at birth
17-α-OH lase & 11-β hydroxylase deficiency present with hypertension

questions.text: False statement regarding congenital adrenal hyperplasia is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia 
i) Hypertension is present in 
a. 17 hydroxylase deficiency 
b. 11 hydroxylase deficiency 
ii) Salt wasting crisis is present in 
a. 21 hydroxylase deficiency 
b. 3βHSD deficiency 
iii) Increased androgens is present in 
a. 21 hydroxylase deficiency 
b. 11 hydroxylase deficiency 
iv) Decreased androgens is present in 
a. 17 hydroxylase deficiency 
b. 3βHSD deficiency

questions.text: A 7 years old girl, presents with recurrent onset of genu valgum and difficulty in walking. On X-ray there is metaphyseal widening and osteoporosis. Serum Ca 9mg/d, serum phosphorus 2.5mg/dL and Alkaline. Phosphatase 30 KAU. PTH level is normal.There is also history of rickets in brother and mother. Probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

X – Linked hypophosphatemic rickets 
• Most common form of refractory rickets 
• Most common mode of inheritance x – linked dominant 
• “phex” gene located on xp22 locus is affected 
• Increased level of FGF – 23 levels (fibroblast growth factor 23). This causes impaired proximal tubular reabsorption of phosphate leading to hypophosphatemia

Laboratory findings 
A. Serum calcium – normal 
B. Serum phosphate – decreased 
C. Parathormone level – normal 
D. 1,25 (oh)2 d3 are low

questions.text: A 10 years old girl is brought to OPD by her parents who are worried the she is shortest girl in her class. Her height is 100.5 cm and her weight 26 Kg. The rest of her physical examination shows nothing abnormal. Her father is 175 cm tall and her mother, who attained menarche at the age of 16 years, is 165 cm tall. The patient’s wrist X-ray show a bone age of 8 years, diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Constitutional delay in growth
I. Most common cause of short stature in mid-childhood period
II. Birth weight and height are normal. Growth of the child lags behind their peers during the prepubescent phase and pubertal spurt in growth is delayed. 
III. Ultimate height is normal.
IV. Bone age (skeletal maturation) is less than chronological age
V. Upper segment: lower segment is normal.
VI. Human growth hormone level and gonadotropin (after puberty) are normal.
VII. Family history of delayed puberty in one or both the parents

choices.text: It does not disappear within 2-3 days
It is a diffuse oedematous swelling of soft tissues of scalp

questions.text: Characteristics of caput succedaneum include all of the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

choices.text: Reassure the mother that nothing is abnormal

questions.text: A full term baby, exclusively breast-fed, at the end of 1 week was passing golden yellow stool and found to have adequate hydration with normal systematic examination. The weight of the baby was just same as it was at birth. The paediatrician should now advice:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

As there is no loss of weight there is no intervention required. Golden coloured stools are normal in this age.

choices.text: Serum albumin level is generally less than 2.5 g/dL
Serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels are elevated
Renal biopsy is not required for diagnosis in most children

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the lab findings of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Minimal Change Disease 
• Most commonly appears between 2 to 6 years of age 
• No hypertension and gross hematuria (Nephritic features are absent)
• Complement C3 level is normal 

Clinical Features 
1. Nephrotic range proteinuria 
• >3.5 gm/24 hours or urine protein : Creatinine ratio > 2
2. Hypoalbuminemia ≤ 2.5 gm/dL – due to urinary losses of protein 
3. Hyperlipidemia
• Cholesterol > 200 mg/dL
4. Lipidiuria
5. Edema

questions.text: A term infant is born with a Patent Ductus Arteriosus. Its closure can be stimulated by the administration of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Patent Ductus Arteriosus
• Associated with maternal rubella infection during early pregnancy. 
• Blood flows from aorta to pulmonary artery. 
• Enlargement of left atrium and left ventricle. 
• Continuous or machinery murmur is present. It is best audible in left infraclavicular area. 
• Most common cause of death in adults is congestive heart failure. 
• Treatment 
Preterm child – prostaglandin inhibitor i.e. Indomethacin or ibuprofen 
Term child – surgery

questions.text: Newborn is having cicatricial rashes in dermatomal distribution. This is suggestive of infection by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Congenital Varicella Syndrome:
• Mother with primary maternal VZV infection can transmit the disease in the first or second trimester causing congenital varicella syndrome.
• Congenital varicella syndrome is not seen in mother having zoster.
Clinical features:
1. Cicatricial skin rash in dermatomal distribution.
2. Asymmetrical muscular atrophy with limb hypoplasia.

choices.text: Goes upstairs one foot per step
Goes downstairs one foot per step

questions.text: Child can make tower of 10 cubes, gate of 3 cubes. What other milestone will be seen in such a child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Walking
a) 11 months:  Walks 2 hands held
b) 12 months:  Walks one hand held
c) 15 months:  Walks without help 
d) 18 months:  Runs 
e) 21 months:  Walks backwards 
f) 2 years:  Goes up and down stairs alone
One step at a time, i.e. two feet per step
g) 3 years:  Goes upstairs one foot per step
Goes downstairs two feet per step
h) 4 years:  Goes downstairs with one foot per step

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice in a pregnant lady at 18 weeks of pregnancy with past history of delivering a baby with Down’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In a couple already having a child with Down syndrome in next pregnancy direct confirmatory test is required. Here given is 18 weeks so answer will be amniocentesis.

choices.text: Aspirin must be given during spike of fever

questions.text: Which is false about febrile convulsion:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aspirin is not given in febrile seizure
  Febrile seizures
  Characterized by:
1. Occur between the age of 6 & 60 months with a temp. Of 38ºc or higher.
2. Are not due to central nervous system infection or any metabolic imbalance
3. No history of prior Afebrile seizures.
4. Febrile statusepilepticus – febrile seizure > 30 min

questions.text: A child presents to the clinic with history of seizures and mental retardation. Clinical examination reveals multiple hypopigmented macules. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tuberous sclerosis:
A) Autosomal dominant.
B) In TSC-1 abnormality is on chromosome 9 encoding a protein called hamartin& in TSC-2, abnormality is on chromosome 16 encoding protein tuberin.
Clinical manifestations 
Major features 
 
• Cortical tuber 
• Subependymal nodule 
• Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
• Facial angio fibroma
• Ungual or periungual fibroma 
• Hypopigmented skin lesions – ‘ash leaf like’
• Shagreen patch – in lumbosacral region
• Retinal harmartomas
• Rhabdomyomas of the heart
• Angiomyolipomas of the kidney
• Pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis

questions.text: 7 month old child is referred to the emergency department with worsening cough. He was born term and has been well till now. On examination temperature is 37.6°C, respiratory rate 70/mt, and heart rate 130/mt. He has moderate intercostal recessions and his arterial oxygen saturation are 88% in room air. Auscultation of his chest reveals bilateral scattered fine crepts. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute bronchiolitis 
• Etiology – respiratory syncytial virus 
• Acute bronchiolitis is usually preceded by exposure to an older contact with a minor respiratory syndrome within the previous week.
• Infant first has mild upper respiratory tract infection with sneezing &rhinorrhoea. This is usually accompanied by decreased appetite and fever of 38.5 - 39°c
• On physical examination – wheezing and fine crepts (bilateral)
• Hyperinflation  can permit palpation of the liver & spleen 
CXR – hyperinflation with patchy atelectasis.

choices.text: Intravenous methyl prednisone followed by oral prednisone

questions.text: 3 year old boy has history of high grade fever, continuous since one week. Child is conscious, irritable, and normotensive with no neck stiffness. There is redness of palms and soles, conjunctival congestion and left sided cervical lymphadenopathy measuring 2 cm in size. Best appropriate treatment is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Features suggestive are of Kawasaki disease 
Most important point to remember is that there is unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Most appropriate treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin

questions.text: 2 year old child has been diagnosed as having Simple febrile seizure. All of the following are true regarding this except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Febrile seizures are seen between 6 to 60 month of age. Features of simple febrile seizure are
a. Duration less than 15 minutes 
b. No recurrence within 24 hours 
c. Generalized 
d. No prophylaxis is required 
e. No EEG and MRI

questions.text: Child was diagnosed as having Down’s syndrome art birth. On karyotyping it is 47, XY (t21). All of the following findings can be seen at birth except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Most common karyotype in 
Down syndrome is trisomy 21. 
Features which are present at birth is 
A. Hypotonia
B. Upward slant of palpebral fissure 
C. Single transverse palmer crease – simian crease 
D. Duodenal atresia 
E. Hypothyroidism 
F. Endocardial cushion defect

questions.text: 12-month old child weighing 6 kgs has come with history of watery diarrhea since one day. Child is irritable, thirsty and skin turgor on recoil is less than 2 seconds. Amount of ORS required for 4 hours is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Features given are suggestive of some dehydration. According to IMNCI, plan B is to be followed. ORS 450 ml @ 75 ml/kg for 4 hours

choices.text: Wide and open posterior fontanel at birth

questions.text: Hypothyroidism is the most common preventable  cause of mental retardation. Which of the following findings is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A Screening for hypothyroidism is to be done between 2 – 5 days after birth by measuring T4 and TSH .Cord blood screening is recommended if there is 
A. Family H/O congenital hypothyroidism 
B. H/O mother taking antithyroid drugs in pregnancy

choices.text: Constitutional delay in growth and puberty

questions.text: 10 – year old girl is brought by mother that the girl is short and not growing. Father height is 176 cm and mother is 164 cm. Mother had Menarche at the age of 15 years. Weight of the child is 30 kgs. Most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Both father and mother is of normal height so familial short stature is ruled out. 
As there is no facial dysmorphology growth hormone deficiency is ruled out 
Weight is appropriate for age, so nutritional deficiency is ruled out. 
Most likely diagnosis is constitutional delay in growth and puberty.

questions.text: 37 weeks gestation born by normal vaginal delivery has HR < 100 / min at birth. Positive pressure ventilation was started and after 30 seconds heart rate is 50/min. Next step is to do
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

If in a newborn heart rate does not improve even after giving positive pressure ventilation, then first ventilation corrective steps are done
M – Mask readjustment 
R – Reposition the airway 
S – Suction 
O – Open the mouth 
P – Increase PIP 
A – Alternate airway

questions.text: 32-year old pregnant lady is at 18 weeks of gestation. She is referred for Quad screening. All of the following are the components of Quad screen except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Quad screening is done in 2nd trimester for Down’s syndrome. It tells about risk of autosomal trisomy .Components are 
- Inhibin
- β HCG
- Unconjugated estriol
- Alpha fetoprotein 
Pregnancy associated plasma protein A is done in first trimester

questions.text: 2 days child has not passed meconium till now. Both parents are normal with no medical problems. Next step is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Delayed passage of meconium is that child has not passed meconium for 48 hours. Next step is to do gastrograffin enema as it is not only diagnostic but can also be therapeutic.

questions.text: 4 year old child has history of recurrent wheeze and increased cough in night. There is family history of similar problems. Child was given monteleukast once daily. Severity of the disease is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Features given are suggestive of bronchial asthma.
Leukotrienes as monotherapy can be given in mild persistent asthma. Other drug which can be given is low dose inhaled corticosteroids.

questions.text: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma, Retina angioma, pancreatic and epididymal cyst are seen in syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Features given are suggestive of von Hippel Lindau syndrome. 
There is involvement of chromosome 3. 
There is increased risk of 
- Pheochromocytoma
- Renal cell carcinoma (clear cell)

questions.text: 3 year old child was diagnosed as having Nephrotic syndrome. There is no hypertension, hematuria and serum C3 is normal. Child was started on prednisone. Steroid responsive nephrotic syndrome implies that remission is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Most common cause of Nephrotic syndrome in age 2 – 6 years is minimal change disease. In this steroids i.e. oral prednisone is started. Steroid responsive is remission is seen within 4 weeks. Remission means urinary protein : Creatinine ratio < 0.2 for 3 consecutive days.

questions.text: In which of the following congenital heart disease prophylaxis for infective endocarditis is not required
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In atrial septal defect there is no significant pressure difference between the atria so there is no endocardial damage .Prophylaxis for infective endocarditis is not required.

questions.text: 2 year old child has been treated for urinary tract infection next step in management is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Even after first episode of UTI, radiological investigation should be done to rule out underlying cause 
n. < 1> 5 year – USG
